subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] new course for MemRise; new decks for ANKI
msgSnippet: Neat! A few things: - you may want to explicitly note what keyboard layout you re using. I made King Kong (
messageBody:
Neat!

A few things:

- you may want to explicitly note what keyboard layout you're using. I made King Kong (<https://github.com/adiabatic/king-kong>), and to type "Charlotte" I'd press "H5d;jl" (without quotes).

- What's an ingle? (<http://www.memrise.com/course/784058/quickscript-for-beginners/5/>)

- I have trouble recognizing ŋ in the middle of a word, too; I usually end up having to check with a dictionary. I use <http://www.macmillandictionary.com/us/dictionary/british/off_1> at the bottom there's a link to <http://www.macmillandictionary.com/us/options.html> where you can change your default to British English. This won't correct for happy-tensing (<http://phonetic-blog.blogspot.com/2012/06/happy-again.html>), though.

- I never did catch the difference between "et roe" and "eight roe" — and I can't easily tell them apart (SoCal native here). Read seems to prefer "eight roe" for everything in the SQUARE lexical set, but I'm way out of my league here. Can someone fire up the Cowan-signal?

- The font and materials you're learning from seem to have some lingering Shavianisms — <http://www.memrise.com/course/784058/quickscript-for-beginners/8/> reifies "yew", "ian", "ear", "air", "ark", "orb" and "er". While Read explicitly notes [ju] and [ɛər] on the second page of the manual, he didn't bother giving them special names, just as we've never bothered giving special names to ligatures like ffl and fi.


On Sep 26, 2015, at 9:45 AM, trybloganatgmail@... [Read_Alphabet] <Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com> wrote:


Hello to all,


Now I've gotten the QuickScript bug!


I figure my best contribution is to upload a MemRise course on the subject <http://www.memrise.com/course/784058/quickscript-for-beginners/>, and--while I'm at it--make some ANKI decks.


Fun, fun, fun!  I do not know what to do about reconciling Read's English with my own South-Eastern US accent.  For now, I'm tending toward Read's methods, though I often don't agree with his vowels.  And I cannot bring myself to "garage" with a soft "zh".  Other than that, things will sift out.


I welcome your comments, and thank you so much for this site!


Sincerely,


Ben
